entry.title: Re: Enhanced Validation for Concurrent Employment and Global Assignment Conflicts - 2H 2025
entry.content:
Hello, I'd like to explain the business reasons. In my company, many employees are sent abroad on global assignments, and it is common for them to hold concurrent positions while overseas. In these cases, both global assignment and concurrent employment occur simultaneously. As our group is a global company, we frequently send assignees or expatriates to overseas locations. It is very common for these expatriates to take on concurrent roles within the same legal entity or across different entities, or to perform multiple positions while abroad.

Since these cases will continue to occur in the future, it is difficult to make plans even for next year. If these cases are treated as errors, it would have a significant impact on our operations.

entry.title: Using Communication Targets for Outbound RFC Communication in ABAP
entry.content:
For those of you, who want to keep unwanted (you could even say badly dressed) destinations out of their HTTP(S) connections, check out this blog post:
Receiver Validation HTTP - Enhance Your Security by Controlling Destination Usage

In the world of SAP systems, remote-enabled function modules (RFMs) are essential for connecting different systems and running functions remotely.  
In this article, you will be guided through the process of calling an RFM using communication targets. This ensures smooth integration between your SAP system and remote systems. There is even a song about this phenomenon called "Smooth Integrator" . You see what we did there? 

Why should you use communication targets? 
Well, imagine throwing a party and accidentally inviting your ex, your accountant, and that one neighbor who always complains about your music. Nobody wantsunwanted guests crashing their (SAP system) party!
That's what happens when you don't have control over which applications can use which RFC destinations. It's a security and maintainability nightmare.  
 
You might wonder how exactly communication target get to be the "life of the party".
Communication targets and application destinations provide a strong layer that simplifies complex processes. They define how your SAP system connects with external systems. For that we need to use specific configurations known as appplication destinations.  

What is an application destination, you ask?  
Imagine it as the ultimate party planner for your data! 

It's the one responsible for making sure your data arrives at the right place, with the right credentials, and doesn't end up going to the wrong party. You know, like that one time you got invited  to a LAN-Party, but  showed up at a wild rave instead. Oops! 

Let's dive into the technical details.  

When you create a communication target, you need to carefully choose which of the following settings suit you best: 

  • Enforce SAP GUI Support - it ensures application destinations allow GUIs and disallow Websocket RFC.  
  • Enforce Fast Serialization - mandates the use of Fast Serializer for application destinations, preventing issues by disallowing other serializers if the scenario was developed with Fast Serializer.  
  • Default Compression Mode - allows predefined settings for higher compression in WAN scenarios or fast compression in LAN scenarios. 

When using communication targets, you can create an application destination in the transaction APPLDEST.  This process ensures you communicate only with the intended recipients.  
You select your communication target and create a new application destination with a right-click: 

 

 

Then you just need to name it, enter the client and select CPIC for the RFC Type. 

Alright, now you have an application destination. You still need to enter some important details like the host name (it can be retrieved from transaction SM51), instance and which authentication method you want to use. 
Application destinations are crucial component for managing external connections efficiently and securely. And now you have one too. Good for you!
 
If you use Cloud capabilities,  communication targets are now available as well!
Instead of using the traditional APPLDEST transaction, the cloud environment introduces some differences regarding the application destination: 

  • In the cloud, you start by creating a communication scenario for outbound RFC, which defines the interaction between your SAP system and external systems.
  • A corresponding runtime configuration, including a communication arrangement and communication system, must exist for your scenario.
  • When a communication arrangement is saved, the system automatically creates an application destination.  

But wait, there's more!  
 
Communication targets can generally have either multiple or exactly one assigned application destination. If you're calling an RFC service via communication targets in your ABAP code, you use the CALL FUNCTION (â€¦) IN REMOTE SESSION method, it is essential for running the function remotely. It is basically like sending an RSVP to your guest, ensuring they got the invite (you get a response much faster though). 
 
When a communication target has exactly one assigned application destination, the process is straightforward. In cases where a communication target has several assigned application destinations, a few additional steps are required.  
When you have several assigned application destinations, one must pass the name of the relevant application destination to the parameter application_destination when creating the communication target instance. This ensures that the correct destination is used during the remote session. Check out how easy it is:  

 

 

In this example we called the function RFC_SYSTEM_INFO and we wanted to find out the maximal resources. 45 is the result. 
ThatÂ´s a Bingo!

By following alle these steps, you can call RFMs using communication targets, improving the connectivity and functionality of your SAP system.  

Just remember, the key is in the configuration.  It should fit your specific needs, like making sure your party playlist has the right mix of songs to keep everyone dancing, and not just that one weird guy.  We all know that one guy who just loooves to play the DJ, please donÂ´t let him. 

To summarize, communication targets and application destinations let you: 

  • Control which applications can crash which parties (application destinations). 
  • Restrict access to only those who need it. 
  • Avoid runtime errors and security mishaps. 

 

In case you are not a party animal, check out the step by step guide:  
Calling a RFM via Communication Targets

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Serries: Most weekends, I jump out of airplanes with my friends
entry.content:
I began skydiving while I was still in high school.  I trained with several of my school friends, and I made my first jumps just after my eighteenth birthday.  I stayed active in the sport through college but eventually gave it up to start a career and, later, a family.

A return after four decades

When folks from that same high school class began planning a 40th anniversary reunion, a few of us who had been part of that original group decided to celebrate in a special way: by skydiving together again.

It was both nostalgic and eye-opening.

Our first jumps had been made with heavy military gear, round parachutes, and G.I. combat boots. What we came back to was an entirely different experienceâ€”refined equipment, greater emphasis on safety, and the atmosphere of an athletic sport.

In those intervening decades, tandem jumping had become commonplace. Instead of days of training before a first solo jump, beginners can now make a safe, mentored jump strapped to an instructor after just a few hours of preparation. That innovation has made skydiving accessible to millions of people who otherwise might never have tried it.  And the sport has exploded: millions of people now make their first tandem jump in the US each year.

Me, stepping out of a jump plane at 13,500 feet. (Photo: Michael Houston)

For me and my friends, that reunion jump lit a spark. We remembered how much we loved this sport.

That was five years ago.  I have been active in the sport ever since.

Skydiving today spans many disciplines: wingsuits that let people glide like a bird, precision accuracy competitions where landing within millimeters of a target is the goal, or â€œmovementâ€ dives where jumpers press their bodies against the wind to cover distances across the ground.

My passion is Formation Skydiving - jumping in groups to build patterns in the sky. Sometimes these formations involve dozens or even hundreds of people, sometimes requiring multiple aircraft flying in formation and â€“ always - deep levels of focus and discipline for the jumpers to succeed.

A formation skydive thatâ€™s going well - over Southern California â€“ me, on the right leg of the gent in yellow.
(Photo: Xian Cam Xtreme Media)

Skydivers come from all sorts of professions.  My skydiving friends are salespeople, accountants, nurses, E.R. doctors, military and police officers. And computer folks - a surprising percentage are computing professionals.  And why is that an indoor and desk bound job also attracts so many of the same people to jump out of planes?  I can offer a guess: when I am dialed into a programming task, the daily distractions of the world disappear.  Time goes away, too.  Psychologists characterize this as something called â€œFlow Stateâ€.  You are engaged and â€œin the momentâ€.  Nothing else matters.  It's a feature of the job that I like. Despite the dramatically different setting, my experience when skydiving brings a similar frame of mind.  Flow State has its own documented rewards.  After a day of jumping, I often have the same upbeat feeling as when I have been on a long run outdoors.

There is a saying floating around the sport, â€œskydiving isnâ€™t for everyone, but everyone should try it once.â€ There is well developed training to prepare you for the safety essentials, but no number of words can prep you for the sights, sounds, and thrill of your first jump.  You just must experience it yourself and today it is more accessible than ever. 

Try it yourself. Come share the skies with me and my skydiving friends.

Next in this series:

Next up, Jan Rumig will be telling you about about long walks and hiking.

entry.title: How Machines Learn: The Science Behind Model Training
entry.content:
Understanding Model Training â€” A Step-by-Step Explanation

One must have heard the buzzwords â€œModel Trainingâ€, â€œMachine Learning", "Model Learningâ€, or â€œAI Modelâ€ quite often â€” whether in tech discussions, product demos, or data science talks.

However, when it comes to explaining what actually happens during this â€œtrainingâ€ process â€” in plain English or even in technical terms â€” most people are left guessing. Is the model memorizing data? Is it adjusting something inside? What exactly is it learning?

In this blog, letâ€™s peel back the layers and understand what truly happens when a model is trained â€” step by step. Weâ€™ll start from a simple analogy and then gradually move into the math behind the learning process. The goal is to make the idea of â€œmodel trainingâ€ not just familiar, but intuitively clear.

Analogy: A Child Learning to Throw a Basketball

To understand the model learning process in a simple, non-technical way, imagine a child learning to throw a basketball into a hoop.

Initially, the child doesnâ€™t know how much force to use. On the first try, the ball falls too short or goes too far. Depending on the outcome, the child adjusts slightly and tries again. After a few attempts, the child improves and starts hitting the target consistently.

Thatâ€™s exactly how a machine learning model gets trained â€” it starts with random guesses, measures how wrong it was, adjusts itself, and improves over many repetitions. It learns not because someone told it whatâ€™s right, but by learning from its own mistakes.

Before We Begin Few Important Notes:

Data as Numbers

To train any model â€” whether for image classification, prediction, or generative AI â€” data must be represented numerically (as integers, decimals, or vectors). In this blog, weâ€™ll skip the mathematical details of data conversion to numeric format. As part of this blog we will take an example of data which is already in numerical form. 

Loss Function

A loss function is like a report card for a machine learning model. It tells the model how well or how poorly it performed on the training data by comparing its predictions with the actual answers. In simple terms, the loss function calculates the difference between what the model's predicted and what it should have predicted. The bigger the difference, the higher the loss â€” meaning the model is doing poorly.

The whole idea of model training is to minimize the loss â€” that is, to reduce the gap between what the model predicted and what it should have predicted with every iteration.

Optimizer

An optimizer is the part of the training process that helps the model to learn from its mistakes. Once the loss function tells the model how wrong it was, the optimizer decides how to adjust the modelâ€™s internal parameters (like weights and biases) to reduce that error in the next round.

Think of it like the modelâ€™s coach or guide â€” after every attempt, it reviews the modelâ€™s performance (using the loss value) and gives it small, calculated corrections to move it closer to the right answer. Technically, an optimizer updates the modelâ€™s parameters ensuring that with every step, the modelâ€™s predictions improve.

Popular optimizers include Gradient Descent, Adam, RMSProp, and SGD.

Optimization step & Learning rate

Optimization step

An optimization step is the actual moment when the model updates its internal parameters (like weights and biases) based on what it learned from the loss function. The optimization step applies the gradients calculated in previous steps to make the model slightly better than before.

You can think of it as the model taking one step forward in the right direction toward minimizing the loss.
Over many such steps (iterations or epochs), the model gradually â€œlearnsâ€ the best parameter values.

Learning Rate

The learning rate, often denoted by the Greek letter Î· (eta), controls how big each optimization step should be. Itâ€™s a small numerical value that determines how quickly or slowly the model updates its parameters.

  • If the learning rate is too high, the model might overshoot the optimal point and fail to converge.
  • If itâ€™s too low, the model will learn very slowly and take a long time to reach good performance.

In simple terms â€”
The learning rate is like the step size the model takes while learning.
A good learning rate ensures the model moves steadily toward lower loss without jumping past the goal.

Mathematically: 

wnew = wold âˆ’ Î· Ã— (âˆ‚L/âˆ‚w)
 
Now let's dive into the actual model training part. 

Introduction â€” What Happens When a Model Trains

When we call below code in python:

model.fit()

we are asking the model to learn patterns that map inputs to outputs. Behind this simple command lies a mathematical cycle of prediction, error measurement, and gradual improvement.

In essence: Model training is about minimizing mistakes â€” by repeatedly predicting, comparing, and correcting.
 
To truly understand what â€œlearningâ€ means, letâ€™s dive one level down in the layers with a simple example: linear regression, where a line is fit to the provided data points using gradient descent.

Step 1: Getting the Historical Data and Understanding the Business Ask

To begin any model training process, we need historical records which holds the input and output values required for model training.

Letâ€™s consider the below data points as our historical records, where x is the input and y is the output for our model training. It means that whenever x happened, what was the value of y.

xy
12
24
36

Business problem: Build a model that predicts y for any given x, based on the historical data.

Step 2: Making Predictions (Forward Pass)

Making predictions in world of model training is also referred to as â€œForward Passâ€, where both true input and the true outputs (i.e. historical record samples) are provided to the model for it to start learning.

Since we are considering a linear regression as our example, we use the simple model equation:

Å· = wÂ·x + b

Weâ€™ll start with random model parameters: w = 0 and b = 0, predictions for all (x, y) pairs are:

For three training data points values i.e. in the pairing of (x,y) as per above mentioned historical records:

(1,2), (2,4), (3,6)
xy (Actual)Å· (Predicted)
120
240
360

The model predicts nothing correctly yet â€” it hasnâ€™t learned.

Letâ€™s break down one prediction for better understanding.
For example let us consider the pair (x,y) --> (1,2), where x is the input to the model equation and y is the expected output.
We have our parameters w and b both having value as â€œ0â€.
If we substitute values of w, x and b in above equation, since both w and b are â€œ0â€, the result will be â€œ0â€.
Same thing happens with other paired values of (x,y). Hence all the predicted values are â€œ0â€.

Step 3: Measuring the Error (Loss Function)

We measure how wrong the predictions are using Mean Squared Error (MSE), which is given by:

L = (1/n) Î£(yáµ¢ âˆ’ Å·áµ¢)Â²

Substituting the numbers:

L = (1/3)[(2âˆ’0)Â² + (4âˆ’0)Â² + (6âˆ’0)Â²] = 18.67
So, the loss = 18.67 â€” quite high.

The model now knows how bad it is doing, but not how to improve. Thatâ€™s where gradients come in.

Step 4: Learning from Mistakes (Gradient Computation)

To improve, the model must figure out how changing each parameter (w, b) affects the loss.
This is done using gradients â€” the partial derivatives of the loss with respect to each parameter.

âˆ‚L/âˆ‚w = âˆ’(2/n) Î£ xáµ¢(yáµ¢ âˆ’ Å·áµ¢)
âˆ‚L/âˆ‚b = âˆ’(2/n) Î£ (yáµ¢ âˆ’ Å·áµ¢)

At our current statue (w=0, b=0):

âˆ‚L/âˆ‚w = - (2/3) Ã— [(1)(2) + (2)(4) + (3)(6)] = - (2/3) Ã— 28 = -18.67
âˆ‚L/âˆ‚b = - (2/3) Ã— (2 + 4 + 6) = -8

This tells the model to increase w and b to reduce the loss.

Step 5: Updating the Model (Optimization Step)

Now comes the optimization step â€” where we update parameters in the opposite direction of the gradient, scaled by the learning rate (Î·).

Lets take Î· = 0.1.

We update parameters using the learning rate (Î·):

wnew = w âˆ’ Î·(âˆ‚L/âˆ‚w)
bnew = b âˆ’ Î·(âˆ‚L/âˆ‚b)
 
Plugging in the values:
w = 0 âˆ’ 0.1(âˆ’18.67) = 1.867
b = 0 âˆ’ 0.1(âˆ’8) = 0.8

After iteration 1: w = 1.867, b = 0.8

Training doesnâ€™t stop after one update.
We repeat the process (forward pass â†’ loss â†’ gradient â†’ update) for several epochs, each time bringing the model closer to the true pattern.

Letâ€™s perform one more iteration to see the progression.

Iteration 2

Forward Pass
Å· = 1.867x + 0.8
 
xyÅ· (Predicted)
122.667
244.534
366.401

Loss after iteration 2:

L = (1/3)[(2âˆ’2.667)Â² + (4âˆ’4.534)Â² + (6âˆ’6.401)Â²] â‰ˆ 0.34

Loss dropped from 18.67 â†’ 0.34 in just one iteration!

Compute Gradients
âˆ‚L/âˆ‚w = - (2/3) Ã— [(1)(2âˆ’2.667) + (2)(4âˆ’4.534) + (3)(6âˆ’6.401)] = - (2/3) Ã— [âˆ’0.667 âˆ’ 1.068 âˆ’ 1.203] = 1.86
âˆ‚L/âˆ‚b = - (2/3) Ã— [(2âˆ’2.667) + (4âˆ’4.534) + (6âˆ’6.401)] = 1.73
Update Parameters
w = 1.867 âˆ’ 0.1 Ã— (1.86) = 1.681
b = 0.8 âˆ’ 0.1 Ã— (1.73) = 0.627
 
After iteration 2:
w=1.681, b = 0.627
 
Loss has dropped sharply â€” the model is learning!
 
Loss Summary Table:
IterationswbLoss
11.8670.80018.67
21.6810.6270.34

If we finish the training process after two iterations, the model for the given data would be represented by the equation: Å· = 1.681x + 0.627

Here, the values 1.681 and 0.627 are the learned parameters (weight and bias) that the model has adjusted during training to best fit the data.

The animation attached shows how the regression line gradually adjusts during training for 10 iterations. With each iteration, the model updates its weight (w) and bias (b) to better fit the data points â€” moving closer to the true relationship between x and y.

Additional Note:
For ease of explanation, we considered an example with just one input variable (x).
However, in real-world scenarios, models usually work with multiple input features, represented as xâ‚, xâ‚‚, xâ‚ƒ, â€¦, where each represents a different attribute or factor influencing the prediction.

Intuitive Summary

Model training is guided trial and error mechanism. Each iteration:
  • The model guesses (forward pass).
  • It checks how wrong it was (loss).
  • It learns from the error (gradient).
  • It updates itself slightly (optimization).
  • It repeats until mistakes are minimal.

And thatâ€™s how a simple mathematical routine turns into a â€œlearningâ€ machine or what we proudly call today a â€œMachine Learning Model.â€

entry.title: Implementing the Template Method Design Pattern
entry.content:
The Template Method pattern establishes a common framework for a process while letting derived classes implement their own versions of certain steps.

For example, generating reports in different formats (PDF, Excel, Text) might have differences in export or formatting logic, but the sequence of operations remains the same:

  1. Fetch data

  2. Prepare output

  3. Download or display the result

 

 

 

METHOD fetch_data. 
    DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   ENDMETHOD. 

  DATA: lt_output TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string, 
         lv_filename TYPE string, 
         lv_line   TYPE string. 
 
  " Header line 
   lv_line = |VBELN;KUNNR;VKORG;VTWEG;SPART;AUART;POSNR;MATNR;VRKME|. 
   APPEND lv_line TO lt_output. 
 
  " Data lines 
   LOOP AT gt_data INTO data(ls_sales_data). 
     lv_line = |{ ls_sales_data-vbeln };{ ls_sales_data-kunnr };{ ls_sales_data-vkorg };{ ls_sales_data-vtweg };{ ls_sales_data-spart };{ ls_sales_data-auart };{ ls_sales_data-posnr };{ ls_sales_data-matnr };{ ls_sales_data-vrkme }|. 
     APPEND lv_line TO lt_output. 
   ENDLOOP. 
 
  "------------------------------------------------------------ 
   " Download to file 
   "------------------------------------------------------------ 
lv_filename  = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output1.txt'. 
 
  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
     EXPORTING 
       filename     = lv_filename 
       filetype     = 'ASC' 
     CHANGING 
       data_tab     = lt_output 
     EXCEPTIONS 
       OTHERS       = 1 
   ). 
 
  IF sy-subrc <> 0. 
     MESSAGE 'Error during file download' TYPE 'E'. 
   ENDIF.

 

 

 

METHOD fetch_data. 
 
    DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   ENDMETHOD. 
DATA(lo_pdf) = NEW cl_apoc_pdf_generator( ). 
     lo_pdf->create_pdf( 
       EXPORTING 
         input             = gt_data 
       RECEIVING 
         pdf_binary_output = DATA(rv_bin) 
     ). 
 
    DATA: lv_bin     TYPE xstring, 
       lt_bin_tab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255, 
       lv_size    TYPE i, 
       lv_filename TYPE string. 
 
lv_bin = rv_bin.  " Your PDF xstring 
 
" Convert XSTRING to BINARY TABLE 
CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY' 
   EXPORTING 
     buffer        = lv_bin 
   IMPORTING 
     output_length = lv_size 
   TABLES 
     binary_tab    = lt_bin_tab. 
 
" Set filename (local path) 
lv_filename = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output.pdf'. 
 
" Download to frontend 
cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
   EXPORTING 
     bin_filesize = lv_size 
     filename     = lv_filename 
     filetype     = 'BIN' 
   CHANGING 
     data_tab     = lt_bin_tab 
   EXCEPTIONS 
     OTHERS       = 1 
). 
   endmethod.

 

 

 

 

DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
 
 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   endmethod. 

 

 

DATA: lo_salv_table TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table. 
DATA: rv_excel_bin TYPE xstring. " Holds the final XLSX binary data (XSTRING) 
 
" 1. Create ALV instance from the internal table 
TRY. 
     cl_salv_table=>factory( 
       IMPORTING 
         r_salv_table = lo_salv_table 
       CHANGING 
         t_table      = gt_data 
     ). 
 
" 2. Generate the XLSX binary data (XSTRING) 
     lo_salv_table->to_xml( 
       EXPORTING 
         xml_type  = if_salv_bs_xml=>c_type_xlsx  " Specify XLSX format 
       RECEIVING 
         xml       = rv_excel_bin 
     ). 
 
  CATCH cx_salv_msg. 
     " Handle ALV/XML generation error 
     MESSAGE 'Error during XLSX generation' TYPE 'E'. 
     RETURN. 
ENDTRY. 
 
* The rest of your download logic can remain similar, 
* but I'll use CL_BCS_CONVERT=>XSTRING_TO_SOLIX as it's often more standard 
* for converting to the format required by GUI_DOWNLOAD's BIN filetype. 
 
DATA: lv_bin      TYPE xstring, 
       lt_bin_tab  TYPE solix_tab,  " Use SOLIX_TAB for better compatibility 
       lv_size     TYPE i, 
       lv_filename TYPE string. 
 
" Move the generated Excel XSTRING 
lv_bin = rv_excel_bin. 
 
" Convert XSTRING to SOLIX (Binary Table for GUI_DOWNLOAD) 
* SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY is still an option, but CL_BCS_CONVERT is often preferred. 
 
 
lt_bin_tab = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( iv_xstring = lv_bin ). 
 
" Get the size of the XSTRING for GUI_DOWNLOAD 
lv_size = xstrlen( lv_bin ). 
 
" Set filename (local path - user will be prompted) 
" IMPORTANT: Use a generic name unless you want a fixed path 
lv_filename = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output56.xlsx'. " Using 'C:\...' forces a specific path, better to use a simple name 
 
" 4. Download to frontend 
cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
   EXPORTING 
     bin_filesize = lv_size 
     filename     = lv_filename 
     filetype     = 'BIN' " Must be 'BIN' for binary files (like XLSX) 
   CHANGING 
     data_tab     = lt_bin_tab 
   EXCEPTIONS 
     OTHERS       = 1 
). 
 
IF sy-subrc <> 0. 
   " Handle download error 
   MESSAGE 'Error during file download' TYPE 'E'. 
ENDIF.

 

For pdf. 

 

For text type 

 

 

Excel  

 

 

CONCLUSION

 The Template Method Pattern in ABAP provides a powerful way to design reusable and maintainable frameworks, especially when you have multiple processes that share a common structure but differ in certain implementation steps.

entry.title: This article explains the basic Idea and Architecture of SAP BODS
entry.content:
Understanding of SAP BODS?

SAP BODS stands for Business Objects Data Services.

Itâ€™s a tool used to extract data from different systems, transform it into useful information, and load it into a data warehouse.

In short, it helps combine and clean data so that organizations can make better decisions.

It supports data integration, data quality, data processing, and data profiling all in one platform.

Brief History of SAP BODS

  • In 2002, a company called BusinessObjects took over Actaâ€™s tools and rebranded them as BusinessObjects Data Integration and BusinessObjects Data Quality.
  • In 2007, SAP acquired BusinessObjects, and the tools were renamed SAP BODI and SAP BODQ.
  • In 2008, SAP merged both products into one, which became SAP Business Objects Data Services (BODS) the tool we use today.

SAP BODS Architecture Overview

 

SAP BODS has several main components that work together:

 

                                                SAP BODS Architecture Diagram

 

  1. Repository

A repository is like a storage area that keeps all your project details such as metadata, source and target details, transformation rules, and objects created by users.

Each repository connects to one or more Job Servers which run the data jobs.

Repositories help share information with other systems and keep your data environment organized.

 

  1. Management Console

This is a web based tool used to monitor and manage jobs.

You can use it for:

  • Impact and Lineage Analysis
  • Administration and Auto Documentation
  • Operational Dashboards
  • Data Validation and Reporting

 

It gives you a complete overview of how your data flows and performs.

 

  1. Job Server

The Job Server runs your data movement and transformation processes.

It connects to multiple data sources, moves data in batch or real time, and handles extraction from ERP systems.

When you run a job from the Designer, the Job Server takes care of executing it.

 

  1. Data Services Designer

The Designer is where developers build and design jobs.

It has a graphical interface that allows you to drag and drop objects, define transformations, and control data flow.

Itâ€™s user friendly and helps you build workflows and manage repository metadata.

 

  1. Engines

Engines are the components that process your data once a job starts.

They handle extraction, transformation, and loading.

They are designed to perform tasks quickly using parallel processing and in memory transformations to improve speed and scalability.

 

  1. Access Server

This server handles real time messages.

It takes requests, routes them to the correct service, and returns the response within a set time.

This is useful when data needs to be updated instantly.

 

  1. Address Server

The Address Server helps in address validation and correction.

It must be running before executing any jobs that involve address cleansing or global address validation features.

Important Terms in SAP BODS

 

Datastore

A Datastore connects BODS to a data source, such as a database.

It lets you import metadata and provides the link between BODS and your backend system.

 

CMC (Central Management Console)

This is a web based admin tool where you can register repositories, manage users, and perform other administrative activities.

 

Data Integrator Web Administrator (DI Web Admin)

It helps manage repositories and services like job servers, meta repositories, and web services.

This tool keeps everything connected and maintained.

Advantages of SAP BODS

  • It provides high quality data profiling and supports data cleansing and transformation easily.
  • The user interface is simple and allows drag and drop functionality.
  • Itâ€™s quick to learn for beginners and efficient for developers.
  • You can build both batch and real time jobs.
  • It supports custom functions for complex data transformations.
  • It integrates well with SAP and non-SAP systems.

Disadvantages of SAP BODS

  • Itâ€™s expensive, especially for small companies.
  • It needs powerful hardware and sometimes multiple servers.
  • It requires a skilled development team to implement and manage.

Summary

 

SAP BODS is one of the most powerful tools for data extraction, transformation, and loading (ETL).

It allows organizations to connect to different systems, clean the data, and make it useful for reporting and analysis.

While it may cost more to set up, it offers strong performance, scalability, and flexibility for enterprise level data management.

                                                                                                                                                        Published by

                                                                                                                                                         Nikhat Fatima

entry.title: SAP EA - Real World Asset Tokenization with Distributed Ledger Technology on the SAP BTP Kyma ğŸš€
entry.content:
I is for Innovation....   EA is about... the goal of this blog is to get us thinking and talking about tokenization before the Business turn up demanding it...

I've always wished and dreamed that us SAP EA's would know our Business so well and at the same time have Road Maps for all of our Technology Standards and including Emerging Standards so that we would know what Technical Capabilities the Business requires before they even come to us with their Demand.

In reality, in my experience 9 times out 10 it's the Business who come to EA with demands for new technologies (innovations).

How do we bring in or do "Innovation" ? Ideally with Roadmaps and Emerging Technology Standards. 

SAP's next generation Customer CoE guides SAP Guides for Customer COE provide thought leadership on bringing in innovations, Customer Center of Expertise - Strategy, Governance and Organization

and continuous-improvement-and-innovation-with-a-ccoe.pdf

Customer Center of Expertise   

ccoe_continuous_success_en.pdf

In SAP's documentation, in the North Star Architecture, in the next generation SAP CCoE,  innovation responsibilities come in to a number of Roles

And combined with the Digital Innovation Manager Digital Innovation Manager | Digital Technology and Innovation Management| SAP Community

And that is what this blog is about, innovation, and innovation in the area of Tokenization and RWA Real World Asset Tokenization.

There is a silent digital revolution going on, where evidence, assets, transactions are being given a digital fingerprint, a hash on a Distributed Ledger and being tokenized.

What is Tokenization and who's doing it and where is it going ?

Let's start by looking at what's happening in the space:

[Disclaimer - we cannot post links outside of the Community and if you want to read these articles then just go on your favourite search engine and find them]

Pairpoint - Vodafone Sumitomo JV

 

World Economic Forum

 

Fortune - Asia's quiet tokenization revolution

 

CNBC

 

Oracle

from the same article, this is how Oracle sees it:

 

If they all see Tokenization that way then maybe the EA innovation leads in our Organisations should be having a look at Tokenization too.

This older SAP article considered common use cases NFT (Non-Fungible-Tokens) | Digital Technology and Innovation Management | SAP Community

SAP has dipped their toes into the water with the SAP Green Ledger What Is SAP Green Ledger? | SAP Help Portal , in my opinion the scope is too narrow, Green Ledger: Where Carbon and Financial Accounting Unite   SAP Green Ledger and an ERP-centric approach to reinvent carbon accounting   and Carbon Accounting is the tip of the iceberg.

Learning.sap.com has some excellent resources including videos Blockchain  and this incredible Blockchain course What Can Blockchain Do for You .

Have a think about how Tokenization and Distributed Ledger Technology capabilities fit towards your Business, your Business Processes, your Business Partners.

Have a think about drawing the Blockchain Capability Map,  positioning Enterprise Blockchain as an Emerging Technology Standard, and then when the Business come with the Demand... let the use-case / Demand find the Blockchain, and if you want to have a play with Enterprise Blockchain on the BTP Kyma, even the BTP Trial Edition Kyma then just follow this blog and reach out if there are any questions.

And that's the purpose of this blog, to get Tokenization onto our EA radars.

What do you think, put your thoughts in the comments.

Ultimately this is all "Why I love SAP and Blockchain Databases and why you should too ğŸš€".

Andy Silvey.

Independent SAP Technical Architect and SAP Basis SME [you might also find my SAP S/4HANA RISE & BTP Toolbox interesting:  ğŸ§°ğŸ‘·â€ The SAP S/4HANA RISE & SAP BTP - Toolbox ğŸ‘·â€ğŸ§°] and CEO of atkrypto (.) io

Author Bio:

Andy Silvey is a 26 years SAP Technology veteran [26 years SAP Basis and  including 12 years SAP Tech Arch including Tech, Integration, Security, Data from 3.1H to S/4HANA PCE on RISE and the BTP and everything in between, and former SCN Moderator and Mentor alumni].

Andy is also co-Founder of atkrypto inc, an startup whose ambition is to make Blockchain easy for Enterprise.

atkrypto (.) io's flagship product is the atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP,  and atkrypto (.) io is a SAP Partner Edge Open EcoSystem Partner. 

The atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has been designed by SAP Independent Experts for the needs of SAP Customers and to be deployed on the SAP BTP Kyma Runtime Service and leverage native integration to SAP Products.

atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has a number of unique qualities, including being the only Blockchain software in the world which has a DataCenter version and a light mobile version which can run on Edge/IoT/Mobile devices and enables data to be written to the Blockchain at the Edge where that same Blockchain is running on a Server in the DataCenter, protecting the integrity and originality of data from the Edge to Insights. Taking Blockchain to the Data at the Edge instead of taking the Data to the Blockchain.

entry.title: Settings for the automatic creation of cProject from a PPM Item followed by creation of PS Project
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's fast-paced business environment, effective project management is crucial for success. Organizations are increasingly turning to automated solutions to streamline their project creation processes, ensuring efficiency and consistency. This blog explores the settings necessary for the automatic creation of Collaboration Projects (cProjects) or Project Management Projects from a Project Portfolio Management (PPM) item. We will delve into the configuration steps and the benefits of integrating these automated processes into your project management framework. By understanding these settings, project managers / consultants / users can enhance collaboration, reduce manual errors, and ultimately drive project success.

Settings for the automatic creation of cProject (Collaboration Project) or Project Management Project from a PPM Item, followed by the automatic creation of PS Project

To automatically create a cProject from a PPM Item, the Item type must be configured with "Linking to Project System" set to "Portfolio and Project Management."

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Portfolio Management Ã  Global Customizing Ã  Portfolio-Independent Settings Ã  Define Portfolio Item Types

 

You have created a Project template in â€œTemplates â€“ Project Managementâ€ App:

Note: - The Project Template must have a status of "Released"; otherwise, it will not be visible in the configuration node specified below for assignment as a template for the Item type to enable automatic cProject creation.

Assign the template to Item type for creation of cProject (Project Management) automatically from Item:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Portfolio Management Ã  Global Customizing Ã  Portfolio-Independent Settings Ã  Map Item Type to Project or PS or Commercial Project

Assign decision points against Phases of Template Project:

Configure Project type for Project Management Project (cProject):

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Structure Ã  Define Project Types

You can create your own Project Type by copying a standard Project Type and adjusting the necessary settings as illustrated in the screenshots below:

Double click on the Project Type Highlighted in screen shot above:

Make the necessary settings as shown below:

You can check or uncheck various checkboxes according to your business requirements.

For the automatic creation of a PS project from Project Management in PPM, the critical configuration is "Accounting Integration." In this section, the â€œAcc Integ Scenarioâ€ must be set to "A Accounting Integration in ERP," and the Transfer Type should be selected from one of the three options shown in the screenshot above.

  • If "0 Always Automatic When Saving" is selected, the PS Project will be created automatically upon the creation of the cProject, and the status of the cProject will be set to "Created - Transferred â€“ Assignedâ€.

  • If â€œ1 Automatic As of â€˜Flagged for Transfer / To Assignâ€™â€ option is selected, then user has to select the â€œFlag for Transferâ€ option in Status to get the PS Project created automatically from cProject.

  • If â€œ2 Automatic As of Release of Projectâ€ option is selected, then PS project will be created automatically once cProject status is set to Released.

Rest settings you may consider as per your business requirements.

 

Accounting Integration:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Connection to External Systems Ã  Accounting Integration Ã  Activate Integration

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Connection to External Systems Ã  Accounting Integration Ã  Define Object Links for Accounting Integration

Double click on Object Type and Maintain Destination and Web Server

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Connection to External Systems Ã  Accounting Integration Ã  Make General Settings

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Connection to External Systems Ã  Accounting Integration Ã  Define Cost/Revenue Rates

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Project Management Ã  Connection to External Systems Ã  Accounting Integration Ã  Make Settings in SAP S/4HANA System

Note: Post executing this you will be taken to another configuration node of Collaboration project for Controlling integrations:

Configuration Node: Collaboration Projects Ã  Controlling Ã  Create and Change Controlling Scenario

 

Configuration Node: Collaboration Projects Ã  Controlling Ã  Define Controlling Scenario

Note: In the screenshot above, the controlling level indicates the maximum level of WBS that will be created in the PS Project from the cProject. For instance, if you have a cProject with tasks and sub-tasks up to level 4, but you select 2 as the controlling level, the PS Project will be created with the lowest WBS level set to 2.

Configuration Node: Collaboration Projects Ã  Controlling Ã  Settings for Easy Cost Planning

Configuration Node: Collaboration Projects Ã  Controlling Ã  Assign Cost Elements and Activity Types

 

Settings in Common Function:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Common Functions Ã  Decision Flow Management Settings Ã  Attribute Synchronization Ã  Maintain Attributes for Synchronization Scenarios

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Common Functions Ã  Decision Flow Management Settings Ã  Attribute Synchronization Ã  Maintain Field Mappings

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management Ã  Common Functions Ã  Decision Flow Management Settings Ã  Define DFM Object Link Types

Note: It is recommended to perform this configuration in the appropriate system by opening the client, such as the Test or Production system. Otherwise, the TR movement may override the settings.

 

Here, make the settings for all the relevant Object Types, below I have shown example for one Object Type:

Maintain Logical System, Destination and Web Server

Letâ€™s test the scenario:

Item created with ID â€œTESTCPROJ001â€

Select the checkbox â€œCreate Project on Savingâ€ and click on Save.

We can see under Related Objects in Relationship tab cProject created Automatically.

Now letâ€™s see the automatically created cProject:

Status of cProject is â€œCreated - Transferred â€“ Assignedâ€ that means PS Project also created automatically at the time of creation of cProject as per the setting in configuration under Define Project types mentioned in this document above.

In the Accounting Tab of cProject, we can see the PS Project created automatically from cProject.

We can see the same in Project Builder also:

Conclusion

In conclusion, the automatic creation of cProjects and PS Projects from PPM items represents a significant advancement in project management efficiency. By implementing the right settings and configurations, organizations can not only save time but also improve the accuracy and reliability of their project data. As businesses continue to evolve, leveraging automation in project management will be key to staying competitive. We encourage project managers and teams to adopt these practices, ensuring that their project management processes are as streamlined and effective as possible. Embracing these solutions will pave the way for more successful project outcomes and foster a culture of collaboration and innovation within teams.

entry.title: Automate Digital and Physical Together - Intralogistics Fleet Orchestration integrated with SAP EWM
entry.content:
Welcome, my name is Fabio Marti and I am the Vice President of Marketing at KINEXON. With this blog, I am adding to the series Enhancing warehouse operations by integrating robotics with SAP Extended Warehouse Management that has been started by @ganesh_wadawadigi  and explain how KINEXONâ€™s solution for mobile robot fleet management can be combined with SAP EWM to give intralogistics professionals and operations leaders new levels of control and efficiency.  

Managing a warehouse or production site often means dealing with a mix of mobile robots and manually operated forkliftsâ€”each running on different systems. This creates fragmented workflows, manual task assignments, and patchwork of disconnected software. SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) streamlines the operations, but managing and integrating a heterogenous fleet of robots and forklifts can be challenging. KINEXON Fleet Manager eliminates the need for custom middleware or manual coordination for the diverse robot fleet to pull tasks directly from SAP EWM and execute them autonomously and report back in real time. In addition, it also allows to send jobs automatically to manual forklifts to ensure that they are well coordinate with the movement of the robots thereby optimize the execution of the jobs and reduce incidents and increase overall shopfloor efficiency. 

â€ƒ

Connecting the Digital and Physical Worlds 

Integration of KINEXON with SAP EWM addresses the need for a scalable and out-of-the-box integration to address operational challenges such as:  

  • Lack of real-time feedback on task execution, accidents, or other outliers 
  • Risk of collisions and congestions due to forklifts being a digitally invisible free radical in your autonomous transport paths 
  • Need for custom-built middleware for every single vehicle type that is expensive and hard to maintain   
  • Limited scalability when adding new robot types or workflows 
  • Gaps in end-to-end automation, causing inefficiencies and delays 
  • Blind spots, lacking real-time visibility of moving assets 

KINEXON acts as a central orchestration layer between SAP EWM and the intralogistics fleet by bringing together all transport resources - autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), automated guided vehicles (AGVs), forklifts, tugger trains, and even manual carts â€” into one intelligent control system. It uses: 

  • SAP EWM APIs to pull and report tasks that have been optimized for orchestrating warehouse activities based on several factors such as inventory levels, space and resource utilization, travel path, order priority etc. 
  • VDA 5050, a standardized communication interface for AMRs, AGVs and forklifts from different vendors 
  • Out-of-the-box integration for rapid deployment 
  • Real-time logic to assign tasks dynamically and handle exceptions 
  • Real-time tracking of manual vehicles to seamlessly integrate them into the intralogistics flow, enabling end-to-end automation 

This makes the robots become true executors of warehouse orders and tasks that are optimized by SAP EWM, requiring no manual intervention while working smoothly alongside manual transport vehicles, whose paths and locations are also fully digitized. 

KINEXON Fleet Manager functions as an Intralogistics Execution System providing standardized interfaces and integration capabilities for over 20 mobile robot vendors, such as ABB, Jungheinrich, AMOVIO Robotic Solutions, Bosch Rexroth, MiR, Safelog, STILL, and Linde. Each robot vendor is technically certified through standardized interface validation and end-to-end process testing, ensuring full interoperability with SAP EWM; this allows SAP EWM customers to confidently select a robot vendor based on their specific operational and process requirements rather than on integration feasibility.

Integrating SAP EWM with Robot Fleet using KINEXON 

Here is a typical set up of the integration between KINEXON Fleet Manager and SAP EWM: 

  1. Creating Smart Queues in SAP
    KINEXON creates two queues:
    • One for standard warehouse tasks
    • One for tasks that fail or need manual review

KINEXON Fleet Manager keeps an eye on these queues in real time, pulling in tasks as they come.

  1. Defining the Fleet as a Resource
    Next, the Fleet Manager will be introduced to SAP EWM as if it were a workerâ€”literally. A virtual resource (like â€œKINEXON_FLEETâ€) is created so SAP EWM can assign tasks to it just like it would to a forklift or warehouse employee.
  2. Activating the Right APIs
    To make the magic happen, KINEXON activates key SAP EWM APIs: 
    • Warehouse Resource API: for resource creation and status updates
    • Warehouse Order and Task API: for pulling and updating warehouse orders

These APIs can be found on SAP Business Accelerator Hub by searching for â€œwarehouseâ€.

  1. Configuring the Fleet Manager
    Now it is time to sync everything up. In the KINEXON Fleet Manager, customers can configure: 
    • API endpoints and credentials
    • Warehouse number and resource name
    • Polling intervals for task retrieval

This ensures the system is tightly synced with SAP EWM.

  1. Mapping Pickup and Dropoff Points
    Finally, robot navigation points will be aligned with SAP storage bins using simple naming conventions like: 
    • BIN_01-pickup for pickup points
    • BIN_02-drop for drop-off points

This makes sure every robot knows exactly where to go and what to do.

Business Benefits 

Typical benefits of KINEXON Fleet Manager integrated with SAP EWM are: 

  • Less implementation and maintenance effort 
  • Fast return on investments
  • Reduction in stoppage due to better orchestration
  • Higher fleet throughput 

A leading global tier-1 automotive supplier recently piloted the KINEXON Fleet Manager system integrated with SAP EWM to streamline intralogistics with the goal of cutting operational costs and building future-proof automation. 

The company was facing the following hurdles: 

  • Manual forklift operations slowed material transport 
  • No SAP EWM integration limited automation and real-time task execution 
  • Lack of fleet transparency made AMR tracking difficult 
  • Manual trolley handling disrupted AMR flow 
  • Gate control systems were incompatible with AMRs 

The pilot automated supply for a production line with five machines using three AMRs. Fleet Manager received orders directly from SAP EWM, coordinating AMRs for material flows while ensuring real-time tracking, optimized utilization, and on-time delivery to prevent downtime. 

Using SAP EWMâ€™s Warehouse Order and Task ODATA API, KINEXON Fleet Manager automatically synced tasks and reported live progress, providing end-to-end visibility and seamless automation. AMRs handled raw material supply, empty material collection, finished product transport, and returns to the warehouse or packaging areas, navigating configurable Points of Interest (POIs) across production and warehouse zones. 

In summary, the benefits realized were: 

  • Order management & prioritization: Dynamic task allocation based on production needs 
  • SAP integration: Real-time task sync and monitoring via SAP dashboards 
  • VDA 5050 compatibility: Vendor-agnostic AMR support for flexibility and scalability 
  • Plug-and-play AMR onboarding: Minimal setup for new robots

entry.title: Re: How to access and test an extended Fiori app created...
entry.content:
Hello!

To access your extended Fiori app from SAP BAS, you need to configure a Launchpad tile for the app variant, verify deployment via /UI5/APP_VARIANT, and ensure you have roles like SAP_UI2_USER_700 and access to the relevant catalog and group. Also check transport logs and use Launchpad Designer to assign the tile. Request transactions like /UI5/APP_VARIANT, SE80, SICF, SU53, and PFCG if needed for setup and troubleshooting.

entry.title: During OData call, system terminates with short dump RAISE_SHORTDUMP.
entry.content:
RAISE_SHORTDUMP (/BOBF/CX_FRW_FATAL) during SYCM project validation â€“ RFC system failure in destination ZCA100WILP3PWN3IP5BLH33WRVHQCATM

Hello Experts,

Iâ€™m facing a runtime error while executing an OData operation related to SYCM/ATC project validation.

Error Details:
- Runtime Error: RAISE_SHORTDUMP
- Exception: /BOBF/CX_FRW_FATAL
- Business Object: SYCM_APS_I_PROJECT
- Application Component: BC-DWB-TOO-ATF
- Message: â€œSys failure in dest. ZCA100WILP3PWN3IP5BLH33WRVHQCATMâ€

ST22 Analysis:
The dump indicates that the BOPF framework raised a short dump due to a fatal error in the class `CL_SCA_DS_REMOTE_CONNECTION` during validation (`VALIDATE_PROJECT`).
Root cause seems to be an RFC system failure when calling the remote destination above.

What Iâ€™ve checked so far:
- Confirmed that this happens during a SYCM/ATC project validation (possibly remote check configuration).
- I've checked RFC connection via SM59 and it's working.
- OData error log (ST22) shows the same failure message.
- Suspect the RFC destination or remote ATC system is unavailable or misconfigured.

Questions:
1. What is the recommended way to validate or correct the SYCM/ATC remote connection setup for SYCM_APS_I_PROJECT?
2. Is there a standard configuration path or report to test the connection used by SYCM validation?
3. Could this be caused by an inactive or obsolete ATC remote system configuration, and if so, where should that be maintained?
4. Are there known SAP Notes or corrections related to `/BOBF/CX_FRW_FATAL` in SYCM or ATC validation contexts?

Any guidance or experiences resolving this type of RFC failure in SYCM project validation would be greatly appreciated!
@Olga @olgaolga

entry.title: Re: What are the best practices for migrating data from l...
entry.content: For a safe and efficient migration from a legacy CRM to SAP CRM or SAP CX, follow these best practices: start with a detailed data assessment and cleansing to ensure quality. Define clear data mapping and transformation rules aligned with SAP data models. Use SAP tools like SAP Data Services, Migration Cockpit, or SAP Cloud Integration for automation and consistency. Perform test migrations in sandbox environments, validate data integrity, and involve business stakeholders for verification. Finally, document the process, ensure rollback plans, and schedule cutover during low-impact periods to minimize business disruption and ensure a smooth transition.

entry.title: Re: IDoc message variant or function, what difference?
entry.content:
Hi Sandra

the only start functionality i am aware is the intercompany invoice process where you have in MESFCT the value FI or MM. I would quickly analyse the inbound/or outbound FM if there is a coding available - but in my long year experience it's not used often.

If you want to force the outbound IDOC to be split - using MESCOD/MESFCT is the easiest way to achieve. You can also setup "split by one" in RSEOUT00 and then aggregate in your middleware - but if you are in custom FM anyhow - i would definately use MESCOD/MESFCT.

Which field you use is personal flavor. I would more use MESCOD to have some content related split (e.g. Country, Company Code, etc.) and MESFCT more functional related (e.g. UPD, CRE, DEL,...). But as said - just a personal flavor.

Hope that helps.

BR Helmut

entry.title: SAC Total/Sum of story calculated measure incorrect
entry.content:
Hi All. 

I have a story calculated measure which references 3 story restricted measures.  Owing for the need to be dynamic according to user Input Control selections, these restricted measures are created in the story - and not the model.

When applying the "Show totals" setting on the dimension in the rows, the calculated measure is not aggregated, but rather the calculation/formula is also applied at the "Total" level.

For example, in the below table at the row level, "Calculated Trend" = Value MTD / Shift MTD x Shift Full Month.

I am wanting the "Calculated Trend" Total to be the sum of the row Calculated Trend values.

Expected behaviour:

But what is happening is the "Calculated Trend" formula is carried over to the "Total" row...

Current behaviour:

I have tried changing the "Intersecting Client Calculation Priority" but no change takes place.

I wanted to create an "Aggregation" calculated measure with the "SUM" exception aggregation type calculated measure are not available for use in Aggregation caclulations.

Any ideas on how to get the Totals row of a calcualted measure to "SUM"?

Rgds

Anton

entry.title: Berlin, SAP TechED 2025 and the superheroes without capes
entry.content:
Who, at least once in their life, hasnâ€™t wished to meet a superhero? Wellâ€¦ it happened to me.
And the incredible part? I didnâ€™t meet just one, but many. 

Developer Advocates

This is the story of my journey to Berlin,  an adventure that changed me, moved me, reminded me who I am.
This is the story of my SAP TechEd 2025.

It all began months ago, when I received the news: I had won a ticket. I still remember that moment. A mix of disbelief and pure joy.
My heart racing. â€œThis canâ€™t be realâ€¦â€ I thought. But it was. Beautifully, unexpectedly real.

I was so happy I started counting the days like a child waiting for Christmas.

But life, sometimes, has other plans.
Over the last months I went through difficult moments, the kind that drain your energy and steal your voice. Family struggles that made everything heavier. 

 

 

 

For a while, I was certain I wouldnâ€™t make it. That I would have to let that dream slip away.

Until a month ago, I kept thinking: I wonâ€™t be able to go. Then something inside me whispered: Try. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

And here I am. 

 

 

 

 

 

I told you about superheroesâ€¦Because honestly, what else should I call them? @qmacro @RichHeilman @thomas_jung @OlgaDolinskaja @Vitaliy-R  Some of them Iâ€™ve been following in the SAP Community for 20 years.


Like a kid with posters of their idols on the bedroom wall.
If I love my job today, a big part of it is thanks to them. They inspired me, even from afar. Their passion, their knowledge, their generosity, all seeds that grew into my own path.

And when you finally meet them in personâ€¦ you feel small. Really small. Like an ant standing near kind giants. ğŸ˜

A special mention also goes to my beloved ABAP.  Someone said it would disappear, end up forgotten like a language from the pastâ€¦Meanwhile, it simply smiled and proved everyone wrong.
Itâ€™s still here. More powerful than ever.

And being able to use it in a modern environment like Visual Studio Code? Pure excitement for every developer heart that still beats for code. 

Berlin was breathing the future. Artificial Intelligence everywhere,  but not abstract, not distant.
Real. Tangible. Finally programmable.

With Joule Agents and SAP Build, we can create smart automations directly from our development environment. 

 

And that was my biggest spark: AI is no longer an experiment. 

Itâ€™s no longer â€œsomewhere in the future.â€ Itâ€™s here.
Itâ€™s in our hands as developers, ready to turn ideas into real solutions. 

And for those of us who build software every day, that means only one thing: limitless possibilities.

 

 

 

But the best part was the people. The real ones.
The ones youâ€™ve known for years through comments, chats, usernamesâ€¦ and finally get to hug in person.

Like my friend @moshenaveh , whom I finally met face to face. ğŸ˜Š 
And the incredible energy of @david_ruizb , the kindness of @MariettaLopez , the smiles of @Sandra_Solis  , @lauraschmitz , @StephanieMarley @MustafaBensan â€¦ and so many others.

People who look at you and make you feel part of something bigger. A family you didnâ€™t even know you had, until you find yourself inside it. I came back from Berlin different. More teary-eyed than photographed. More inspired than organized. With this growing desire to create, share, buildâ€¦ and hopefully inspire others, the way they inspired me.

Because I finally realized this:

Superheroes donâ€™t fly.
They donâ€™t wear capes.
They donâ€™t have magic powers.

At leastâ€¦ not the kind we imagine.  Real superheroes are the ones who light a spark in your eyes and make you say: 

â€œIf you believe in it, you can do it.â€

entry.title: Marketplace App Deployment & Lifecycle Management Using SAP DevOps Tools
entry.content:
In this discussion, we aim to explore the complete process of deploying and managing the lifecycle of a marketplace app development project using SAP DevOps tools. The goal is to understand how developers, DevOps engineers, and project managers can streamline continuous integration, testing, and delivery within the SAP ecosystem.

Weâ€™ll discuss best practices for:

Automating deployment pipelines for marketplace applications.

Integrating SAP Cloud Platform, CI/CD, and version control systems.

Managing updates, bug fixes, and scalability throughout the appâ€™s lifecycle.

Ensuring security, compliance, and performance optimization in live environments.

Real-world challenges faced during app deployment and how SAP DevOps tools can help overcome them.

What to discuss:

What are your preferred SAP DevOps tools or workflows for marketplace app deployment?

How do you handle version control, rollbacks, and testing in a live environment?

Any insights or lessons learned from your own deployment experiences?

Letâ€™s collaborate and share strategies, tools, and practical insights to make marketplace app deployment smoother, faster, and more reliable.

entry.title: Re: Costing - Activity Types
entry.content:
Hi, 

  • Yes, ideally you should define multiple activity types (e.g., Labour 1, Labour 2, Labour 3) corresponding to the different labor skill categories or rates.

  • This enables you to assign distinct internal activity rates to each labor type, reflecting their actual cost accurately.

  •  
  • If the number of skill categories is large or frequently changing, you can use statistical key figures or cost center hierarchies combined with a smaller set of activity types and then apply rate adjustments.

  • Some organizations use activity price planning to maintain separate rates for each labor category within the activity type.

  • Another approach is to use cost elements or internal orders to add granularity, but this can complicate reporting and data entry.

entry.title: How To get compliant with iFlow Design Guidelines - Define Identifiers To Search In Message
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I use the designguidelines when creating iFlows, but there is one point where I am unable to achieve compliance.

It concerns the following point in the Design Guidelines: Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs.

My current approach:

At the beginning of the iFlow, I have implemented a Groovy script that stores important values for identifying the customer in the CustomHeaderProperty.

Unfortunately, this does not seem to be enough to make me compliant with the Design Guidelines under â€˜Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logsâ€™.

Here is the Groovy script I used:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null){

		def sEquiID = message.getHeaders().get("EquiID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("EquiID", sEquiID);		
        }

		def sOrderID = message.getHeaders().get("OrderID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("OrderID", sOrderID);		
        }

	}
	return message;
}

 

Do you have any idea what else I need to do?

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Introducing Notifications in SAP Road Map Explorer: Stay Updated Effortlessly
entry.content:
Introducing Notifications in SAP Road Map Explorer: Stay Updated Effortlessly

We are excited to announce a new feature in the SAP Road Map Explorer that will improve how you stay informed about updates and changes: the notifications functionality.

The notifications functionality allows you to receive alerts directly within the SAP Road Map Explorer. This means you can react promptly and adjust your strategies without delay.

You can subscribe to notifications for the following elements:

  • Roadmap items
  • Saved roadmaps
  • Favorites
  • Collections
  • Business views

You will be notified when the following changes have occurred:

  • New data
  • Changed data
  • Deleted data

To check your current subscriptions:

  1. Click the "User" button in the top right corner.
  2. Navigate to "Notification Settings".

Here, you can see which categories you are currently subscribed to and manage your notification preferences.

To check which notifications you have received:

  1. Click the "Bell" button in the top right corner.
  2. On the left, you will see all notifications triggered based on the items you have subscribed to.

We believe this new feature will significantly enhance your experience with the SAP Road Map Explorer, making it easier than ever to stay informed and agile in your planning. Your feedback is invaluable to us, so please share your thoughts and experiences as you explore this new functionality.

Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements as we continue to improve the SAP Road Map Explorer to better serve your needs.

Contact us at any time via the email roadmaps@sap.com.

Your SAP Road Map Explorer Team

entry.title: Re: ğŸ“¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi,

thanks for initiating the discussion and contributing!

"All the development artifact generators should refer to this config and propose names accordingly." from @Sivakumar_Subramaniam is an important point IMHO. Esp with the RAP generators, etc. I think this is an important point.

Besides this I would favor  more decentral approach and storing the definition together with the source code seems also a good idea to me.

IMHO different namings conventions could be in use even in one department, eg extending/enhancing existing solutions or creating new solutions could use different conventions.

Some central guidance on naming convention is of cource a good idea, but a rigid central approach to enforcing this dictator like seems not to be a good approach IMHO.

Regards,

 Wolfgang

entry.title: Re: ğŸ“¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi @kilian_kilger, 

option 1 sounds better to me! There should be named sets of rules, to which a (ATC) check could refer. This way a run for package/software component A could use other rules than for B. The sets could even be transportable WB objects.

And imho its not a task of the compiler to check the rules. The compiler should only deal with things related to the language definition, i.e. syntax & sematics. Conventions are for lint-like tools.

But option 2 could be used by the development tools - if the editor knows which rules apply to the object shown, it could evaluate them ad hoc and mark deviations immediatly.

Regarding the persona question: The lead architect for the product is responsible at us.

BR, Holm

entry.title: Extending Standard SAP MDG Data Model (MM) with Custom Fields
entry.content:
This blog is based on our practical experience and learnings from a recent SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) project. We had a requirement to extend the standard SAP MDG Data Model (MM) with custom fields at both Plant and Sales levels.

To achieve this, there are two main approaches available:

  1. Traditional Approach
  2. In-App Extensibility

 

  1. Traditional Approach : Using the traditional approach, adding a custom field requires multiple manual extensions across different layers of the SAP system â€” including:
  • Database tables (e.g., MARC, MVKE)
  • CDS views
  • SOA services
  • OData APIs

During our implementation, while extending the MARC table with a custom field, we encountered the following error:

DBSQL_REDIRECT_INCONSISTENCY â€“ A table could not be redirected

 

SAP has already addressed this issue in SAP Note 2242679 â€“ Redirect inconsistency â€“ Proxy Substitution, which suggests executing the report NSDM_PROXY_SUBSTITUTION for the MARC table to adjust the related CDS view and resolve the inconsistency.

Although this resolves the immediate technical issue, the traditional approach still requires repetitive manual work â€” extending the field individually at every layer (database, CDS, SOAP, and OData). This process is not only time-consuming but also prone to inconsistencies.

2. In-App Extensibility (Custom Fields and Logic)

To overcome these challenges, we adopted the In-App Extensibility approach using the Fiori app â€” Custom Fields and Logic.

This approach allows you to add and manage custom fields in a single step. When a field is created via this app, it can automatically extend the following components (depending on your configuration and enablement):

  • Underlying database tables
  • Relevant CDS views
  • SOAP services
  • OData APIs

This provides a one-stop solution for extending standard SAP objects â€” significantly simplifying the process and reducing development effort.

Extensibility Steps (Using In-App Extensibility)

Follow the steps below to create and enable a custom field using the Fiori App â€“ Custom Fields and Logic.

 

  • Open the Custom Fields and Logic app.

 

  • Click on the â€œ+ (Create)â€ button to add a new custom field.

 

Enter all the necessary information such as:

  • Business Context
  • Label
  • Data Type
  • Length

 

 

Select the services across different tabs where you want to make this custom field available (e.g., Database Table, SOAP Service, OData API, etc.). The SAP MDG Data Model Extension process remains unchanged. You must still follow the standard MDG extension procedure as detailed in the official SAP document:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Click Save to save your configuration.

Click on Publish to enable the custom field.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The publishing process may take a few minutes. Once completed, the fieldâ€™s status will change to â€œPublished.â€

 

 

After publishing:

  • Check the database table (e.g., MARC or MVKE) to ensure the new field is added.
 

 

  • Verify that the field is available in the corresponding SOAP and OData services.
 

 

Verify that the field is available in the corresponding MDC Model.

 

 

 

Note: The Data Model Extension process in MDG remains unchanged. You must still follow the standard MDG extension procedure as detailed in the official SAP document:https://www.sap.com/documents/2015/07/76525357-5b7c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Key Takeaways

  • Traditional Approach: Requires manual extensions at multiple layers; higher maintenance effort.
  • In-App Extensibility: Provides a one-stop, upgrade-safe solution for extending database tables, CDS views, and APIs in a consistent manner.

Acknowledgment

Special thanks to Suresh, Soumya and Aswin for their valuable technical insights and contributions throughout the implementation.

entry.title: Re: To-Do Rematerialization is needed
entry.content:
Hi, 

Did you check the permission role for the user who wants to approve the workflow on the home page? You need to make sure that the 'Prevent Quick Approval of Workflow' is not checked in Manage Workflows. 

When this is checked, the user loses the ability to approve a workflow directly on the Home Page. 

 

Best regards,

Henriette Beek

entry.title: Re: IDoc message variant or function, what difference?
entry.content:
Thanks.

I did a quick investigation concerning the standard invoice process:

  • Inbound: IDoc type INVOIC02. Depending on MESCOD being FI or MM, the customizing (WE57/table EDIFCT) indicates that the inbound function module will be either IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_FI or IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_MRM. There is also a third value FKK / function module IDOC_INPUT_INVOIC_FKK.
  • Outbound: The output invoice customizing in message processing triggers the program RVADAUS1 (table TNAPR where KAPPL = 'V3' and output type = 1/print form), which generates the outbound IDoc, but I can't see how it fills MESCOD; by default I would say that it's empty (after reading the code), the only possibility to fill it with FI or MM would be to use the customer exit EXIT_SAPLVEDF_001 or the method CONTROL_RECORD_OUT_PREPARE of the BAdI SD_INVOICE_IDOC_OUTPUT. Weird. Probably I missed something.

RSEOUT00 is for outbound, in my case I generate inbound IDocs directly. I can't find "split by one" in RSEOUT00, what is it?

One more hint to confirm that it's a "personal flavor" as you say, I can find in WE57 (table EDIFCT) that SAP has used MESCOD for containing either FI or MM for INVOIC02, but has used MESFCT for containing either MM or SD for SPCORD01/SPCSTS01.
